awd_titl_txt: Exploring Ultracold Matter Along the Complexity Axis
awd_abstract_narration:
It is a fundamental notion that simple things can combine into more complex things, and this complexity underlies the rich variety of phenomena that we see in nature. It is therefore important to the progress of science to understand this richness and complexity in as many environments as possible; from many examples will come general ideas about the intricacies of how the world works. This project relies on the recognition that things as seemingly simple as atoms can present surprisingly complex behavior. Specifically, atoms held in the gaseous state at temperatures one millionth of a degree above absolute zero can be measured with high precision that reveal surprising complexity. For instance, the atoms can be pointed in a certain direction, like little bar magnets, and this direction can influence the thermodynamics of the gas as well as the interactions of the atoms with each other, altering their trajectories in sometimes unpredictable ways. On the other hand, the comparative simplicity of the atoms lends hope that these intricacies can be understood in detail, sorting out the parts that might have an underlying simplicity from those parts that are truly chaotic. This work is therefore also an exercise in understanding the capabilities and limits of engineering atoms to particular purposes.

The work proposed will probe in detail new aspects of ultracold collisions that have emerged in recent years. One is the occurrence of an enormous density of resonant states in collisions of lanthanide atoms such as dysprosium and erbium. This circumstance may lead to novel phenomena in many-body gases on the one hand and to new insights into chaotic behavior and dynamics of rethermalization of isolated systems on the other, hence contribute to small-scale nonequilibrium dynamics. Part of this development seeks to bring the techniques of information theory to bear on questions of the structure of complex molecules. A second aspect is the possibility of super-resonant scattering of ultracold molecules, with far higher densities of states than lanthanide atoms. The occurrence of long-lived collision complexes has been empirically verified, and their lifetimes measured. The proposed work will seek to understand the properties of these unusual, four-atom microdroplets, using statistical techniques.

por.por_cntn:
The science of ultracold atoms and molecules is vigorously pursued for applications to both fundamental physics, such as searches for physics beyond the Standard Model, and for technology, such as quantum computing.  Underlying these applications is the basic fact that the samples produced, typically still gaseous even at temperatures just above absolute zero, represent a new kind of physical substance.  Indeed, the gases considered are sufficiently cold that the orientation of electric or magnetic dipoles is frozen in, giving these unusual substances a preferred direction.  Properties such as the speed of sound, propagation of heat, and viscous damping, all depend on the direction in which these the fluid moves, quite in contrast to ordinary gases such as the atmosphere.  These details have been worked out in the present funding period.  Among other things, they point the way toward improved experimental protocols that evaporate the “hottest” molecules from the gas, cooling the rest to the even lower temperatures required of some experiments.

Further, a deep understanding of molecular interactions in the gas is essential in the quest for technological applications.  For example, the work has found a way to analyze experimental data in order to extract the “scattering length,” a technical property that enables researchers to influence the gas at will. Knowing how to measure this quantity enables researchers to make the atoms or molecules hit each other either gently or strongly, giving them the chance to create intricate scenarios that probe fundamental issues of many-body physics.

A second novel feature of these gases is known as “sticky collisions,” where molecules do not simply bounce off one another as one usually expects, but rather can become entangled in an intricate dance.  These collisions are on the one hand disruptive to experiments and must be understood in order to make progress in the field.  But on the other hand, they challenge our understanding of issues such as the boundary between quantum mechanics (without which one cannot understand behavior at cold temperatures) and classical mechanics (which is, at least up to a point, relevant to the detailed motion of the atoms in the collision complex).  The work in the present funding period has illuminated aspects of sticky collisions, demonstrating that the unusually long time scales on which the molecules appear to stick can be qualitatively understood, provided one approaches the problem from the proper perspective, fusing classical and quantum mechanical theoretical observations.  Further, the work has quantified the way in which sticking increases with electric fields, providing a control parameter with which  experiments may be able to probe the phenomenon in more detail.
